the Curiosity rover has been beating us
over the head with its findings for the
last couple of months and as such its
released another chunk of very
interesting data in this Thursday's
issue of the journal Science the results
are from the first scoop of Martian soil
curiosity ever analyzed in October 2012
it took a spoonful from a pile of dirt
and dust named rocknest heated it up in
an oxygen-free chamber and measured what
gases it gave off using a gas
chromatograph mass spectrometer and
tunable laser spectrometer - talked
about last week and it turns out the
soil has lots of water two percent by
weight which is really high now we know
that there was water on Mars there's ice
caps on the poles in a little water
vapor in its atmosphere but the fact the
surface is covered in even small amounts
of water is pretty exciting as the
study's lead author dr. Laurie lechon
said to the press and I quote we now
know there should be abundant easily
accessible water on Mars when we send
people they could scoop up the soil
anywhere on the surface heat it just a
bit and obtain water and if you're
thinking that one sample can't be used
it's proof that there's water all over
the place keep listening because
curiosity also found compounds in its
rock nest sample that NASA thinks came
from far away mountainous areas
specifically the ratio of isotopes or
variations in elements in those
compounds were very similar to ratios
and Mars's atmosphere these findings
suggest that the water was distributed
moved around the planet which is a big
deal scientists are calling the surface
of Mars the global layer meaning that
the surface soil gets picked up by dust
storms and redistributed so a scoop of
dirt from one spot is an accurate model
of Mars as a whole and that model has a
whole lot of water in it another
significant model this week had a lot of
history in it a group of anthropologists
and mathematicians joined forces to
create a computer model that accurately
predicted where and when complex
societies like empires and states
developed they published their results
the Proceedings of the National Academy
of Sciences on Monday the model was
based on a map of Africa Europe and Asia
around the Year 1500 BCE with a bunch of
geographical and ecological factors put
in including what groups lived where the
researchers also plugged in where and
when certain innovations took place that
had to do
with warfare like the invention of
chariots of the domestication of horses
their hypothesis was that warfare
encouraged the evolution of complex
societies because the groups that work
together were the ones that survived
wars
so they put those factors to the test
running the model for three thousand
years forward to the Year 1500 and the
computer model predicted with sixty five
percent accuracy when and where
large-scale societies arose according to
the scientists this suggests that
warfare is the driving force behind the
evolution of large complex societies and
also that two computers at least warfare
itself is pretty predictable the authors
say it mostly comes down to geography
where people live in close proximity to
each other and where they have fewer
resources to share in fact they know it
historically one of the strongest
indicators for warfare was your
proximity to grasslands in the habited
by nomads especially if they were really
good at writing horses because they
tended to roam farther and compete more
for resources while spreading the
technology of war yes we're looking at
you Mongols even though the Mongols were
the exception to many of the major
trends in world history in this case
they were the rule using their
innovations in warfare and making the
most of their geography they pillaged
their way to becoming one of the most
influential cultures in Eurasia so it
looks like history isn't just a
collection of random events after all
there are larger mechanisms at work and
the better we understand these
mechanisms
maybe we'll be better at shaping our
